title: Stop making assassins that heal for % damage taken.
body: So far it has been on {{champion:245}}, {{champion:107}} rework, and {{champion:555}}. Every time you put this mechanic on an assassin it was a contributing factor in why you had to revisit the champion to stop tank/bruiser builds. This is a mechanic that belongs on tanks because it inherently favors taking as much damage as possible without dying. The more damage you take with such a mechanic, the more effective HP it results in. You may as well put armor or MR scaling on an assassin.

It's very interesting, indeed, to see how previously high-damage, selfish items are being turned into utility ones for Pyke.

It's why I loved the idea of Ashe as a support (as well as the absurd mix of items). You could go {{item:3302}} {{item:3085}} {{item:3071}} {{item:3504}} {{item:3147}} and in theory it all worked out, because, despite having items from 5 separate classes, they all worked together *because* of Ashe's kit. You could apply a semi-AoE armor shred+slow, and when your ADC attacked them they'd get a small heal and Ardent's buff, you'd have Duskblade to clear wards easily, your E *for* vision, gave heals by killing minions...And you took Duskblade, BC, and Runaan's, usually only used by "greedy" champions, and used all three as goddamned *support items*. And it's nice to see the same thing happening for Pyke, seeing weird builds that don't even make *sense* on a support actually being great for a support.

to be fair towards Rengar, he was not designed around being an obligatory assassin. 

He was supposed to be a champion who had options, from tank to bruiser to assassin, and who could play a range of builds. And at the time, the idea of sustain as a necessary jungle / top lane mechanic was pretty prevalent (even though this was never a truth)

Rengar being known specifically for being an assassin stems from his assassin pattern being reliable enough, that his players wanted to play him exclusively for that. i,e, if a champion can have an assassin play pattern, its players will heavily push towards the champion to be balanced around being an assassin. (same as happened with Ahri)

basically a singular identity, because it was very popular and desirable, took over the entire thought around a champion that is originally not designed to be constricted to it.
